DOCNAME: C. B. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
TEXT: The applicant , ORG , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She is represented before ORG , practising in GPE .
The applicant was born on DATE .

On DATE , the applicant was assaulted by her mother ’s boyfriend . She suffered severe injury – left hemiplegia , blindness and severe mental impairment . She required full time care provided by her grandparents who were appointed her legal guardians .

On DATE , the applicant ’s grandparents made an application on her behalf to ORG ( " CICA " ) . They instructed solicitors to present her claims to the ORG . The solicitors obtained inter alia medical reports and reports as to her future needs ( care , accommodation , transport , holiday etc ) . The fees exceeded ORG CARDINAL . Pursuant to ORG , costs of representation in pursuing a claim were not recoverable ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .
By letter dated DATE , ORG informed the applicant that they were minded to make an interim award of GBP CARDINAL . The applicant ’s solicitors responded by insisting that they issue a final award .

By letter dated DATE , ORG informed the applicant that they had made a final award of GBP CARDINAL,CARDINAL . They rejected the large claim for future costs once she became an adult on the basis that these would be largely met by the local authority .

In DATE , ORG informed the applicant that they had reviewed the award and would increase it to the statutory maximum of GBP CARDINAL,CARDINAL . The applicant ’s solicitors and ORG have been in subsequent negotiation concerning the type of trust that should be set up to administer the fund . Apparently the money has yet to be transferred .
Meanwhile , in DATE an action was taken on her behalf challenging the compatibility of paragraph CARDINAL of the Scheme with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention and LAW No . CARDINAL .
On DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s claims . Mr ORG noted :

" It has never been in doubt that her claim is well - founded and can not be subject to any reduction on the grounds of her conduct or character . The only issue for the ORG to decide has been the amount of compensation which should be awarded to her . On any view it was always going to be substantial . "

He found that the obligation for an applicant to make out his case did not require him to obtain at his own expense all the professional reports necessary to prove the nature and extent of his injuries and their impact upon his life and the cost of alleviating it . Once he had demonstrated significant injury and that cost would be incurred in alleviating it , the burden of investigating both elements fell on the ORG . Under paragraph CARDINAL , the ORG were , however , under no obligation to reimburse costs of representation , including drafting and submitting the application , advising on the application , negotiating with the ORG and responding to the ORG ’s queries . Although a well - founded claim to compensation under the ORG was acknowledged by all parties to be a " civil right " under LAW , he did not consider that the requirement under the scheme for applicants , who chose to obtain legal representation to assist in their claims , to bear those costs either restricted their ability to apply to the ORG or deprived them of a fair determination of their claim . He rejected the claim of the discriminatory effect on the applicant ’s pecuniary rights due to her position as a severely handicapped child , considering that the applicant was in the same situation as anyone with a complex claim who would be likely to want to seek some professional legal advice . Further the applicant ’s grandparents could make any decisions which an adult could make .

On DATE , after a hearing , ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal . It noted that meanwhile the ORG had accepted that they should pay for various medical and expert reports and commented strongly on the delay in making a final award , where the severity of her injuries plainly fell in the highest tariff category . It seemed to have been principally because of the ORG ’s dilatoriness that the applicant ’s solicitors became engaged in establishing each element of her claim and bespoke specialists’ reports and counsel ’s advice in order to do so .

Lord Justice PERSON noted that the parties agreed that Article CARDINAL applied to the scheme but considered that as the scheme had operated in this case no violation of the applicant ’s rights arose :

" ... ought the Scheme , in order to comply with C. ’s LAW right to a fair hearing provide for the reimbursement of her solicitor ’s full bill of costs ? This now exceeds GBP CARDINAL ; it covers a wide range of inquiries and the fees of leading and junior counsel . C. has never faced the prospect of being unable to pay these costs , and because of the willingness of her solicitors to defer payment her lack of funds and that of her grandparents has not impeded her access to the ORG . I am less impressed by PERSON argument ( though it found favour with ORG ) that , so long as she has competent adults to act for her , C. is at no disadvantage at all . Given the unnecessarily complex course taken by the ORG , the grandparents were as much in need of advice and representation as C. was .

But C. ’s situation , even so , is not analogous with PERSON , nor with that of an impecunious claimant needing to establish a primary entitlement . Her situation is that of a person whose right of access to the ORG is recognised and effective ( though impeded by prevarication ) but whose carers , very reasonably , want to ensure that the award she obtains is as full as it should be . To that end they have committed a part of the eventual fund to obtaining representation . It is the intent of the Scheme that where this happens it is not to be at the ORG ’s expense . That the Scheme could have provided otherwise is clear ; but it does not follow that it was bound to provide otherwise in order to give effect to FAC right ...

In my judgment it has not been shown that the Scheme invades C. ’s human rights in this regard . It diminishes her award by the cost of her representation ; but while many people would regard this as unfair , it does not deprive her of the possibility of a fair hearing within the meaning of LAW ... "
On DATE , written confirmation was received that ORG refused leave to appeal finding no arguable point of law of general public importance .
Compensation for persons who suffered criminal injuries was provided for originally by an exercise of ORG . The modern statutory scheme was set up under LAW DATE .
Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , it is provided that :
“ The Secretary of ORG shall make arrangements for the payment of compensation to , or in respect of , persons who have sustained one or more criminal injuries . ”
At the relevant time , the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme DATE laid out the applicable rules .
Paragraph CARDINAL :
" It will be for the applicant to make out his case ... Where an applicant is represented , the costs of representation will not be met by the ORG . "
Paragraph CARDINAL :

“ Where a claims officer considers that an examination of the injury is required before a decision can be reached , the ORG will make arrangements for such an examination by a duly qualified medical practitioner . Reasonable expenses incurred by the applicant in that connection will be met by the ORG . ”
Section CARDINAL ) provides :
“ It is unlawful for a public authority to act in a way which is incompatible with a Convention right . ”
Section CARDINAL provides :

“ ( CARDINAL ) In relation to any act ( or proposed act ) of a public authority which the court finds is ( or would be ) unlawful , it may grant such relief or remedy or make such order , within its powers , as it considers just and appropriate .
( CARDINAL ) But damages may be awarded only by a court which has power to award damages , or to order the payment of compensation , in civil proceedings . ”
